qa_pairs.question: What is the nature of the business Sunshine Powers owns?
qa_pairs.answer: Sunshine Powers owns Love on Haight, a legacy business and an artist collective of over 200 tie-dye artists.
qa_pairs.source_text: my name is sunshine Powers I own Lavon hate on the corner of hate and Masonic we are a legacy business and a artist Collective of over 200 tie-dye artists

qa_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the non-profit founded by Sunshine Powers?
qa_pairs.answer: The non-profit, Colors of Love, is a women's prisoner re-entry tie-dye program and a tie-dye education center for the community.
qa_pairs.source_text: I also own the non-profit colors of Love on stanyan or I founded the non-profit colors of Love on stanyan and Frederick Street we are a womens prisoner re-entry tie-dye program as well as a tie-dye education center for the community

qa_pairs.question: How did Sunshine Powers' early experiences in the Haight influence her?
qa_pairs.answer: The Haight made Sunshine feel okay to be herself when she first visited at age 12, especially during a time when she didn't have friends and felt she stuck out.
qa_pairs.source_text: I first came to the hate when I was 12 and in high school and I didnt have any friends and really stuck out and I came to the hate and it um it made it feel okay to be me

qa_pairs.question: What impact did Jerry Garcia's death have on Sunshine Powers?
qa_pairs.answer: Jerry Garcia's death was a significant event for Sunshine as a San Franciscan, and it made it hard for her to return to the Haight after moving away.
qa_pairs.source_text: when I moved away from the city I had a hard time coming back to the hate once I moved back because Jerry Garcia had died when I was 15 and that was very as of San Franciscan it shook us as a city

qa_pairs.question: What challenges did Sunshine Powers face with homeless youth outside her shop?
qa_pairs.answer: Sunshine faced challenges with 40 homeless youth outside her shop, which affected business as tour buses stopped coming due to the homeless problem.
qa_pairs.source_text: one of the biggest issues that I had in the beginning was the 40 homeless youth that were outside of the shop it was not good for business in fact the big tour bus used to stop in front of the shop which was great for the shop and they stopped doing that in 2013 due to the homeless problem that was outside

qa_pairs.question: How does Sunshine Powers' business support homeless LGBT youth?
qa_pairs.answer: The business works with several non-profits to help house homeless youth, 75% of whom are LGBT, who come to the Haight Ashbury from places where it's not okay to be them.
qa_pairs.source_text: we work with several non-profits helping house the homeless youth of our homeless whos 75 of them are LGBT that have come to the Haight Ashbury from Middle America or from the south where its not okay to be them

qa_pairs.question: What is Sunshine Powers' personal housing story in San Francisco?
qa_pairs.answer: Sunshine's parents still live in the same house she grew up in. After the 2008 economic crash, she lived in her parents' basement and then in the Tenderloin for six years before moving to the Haight Ashbury District.
qa_pairs.source_text: my housing story in San Francisco in San Francisco is that you know my parents still live in the same house I grew up in so when the economy crashed in 08 and I lost like everything like a country music song uh I came back and lived in my parents basement because theres thats work to do when you start over and I lived in the tenderloin for six years because it was the only spot I could afford to live by myself

qa_pairs.question: How did Sunshine Powers acquire her shop?
qa_pairs.answer: Sunshine received money from a donor to her homeless youth non-profit to buy the shop, allowing her to reinvest in the community.
qa_pairs.source_text: I received money from one of the donors to our homeless youth non-profit to buy the shop so instead of giving them the money back I get to give all the money back into the community

qa_pairs.question: What challenges did Sunshine Powers face with housing as a woman in San Francisco?
qa_pairs.answer: Sunshine found it difficult to find safe housing and often walked from the Haight Ashbury to the Tenderloin late at night because she didn't feel safe on public transportation.
qa_pairs.source_text: when I was younger and in my 30s was trying to find housing here that I felt safe and as a woman I would walk from the Haight Ashbury to the tenderloin very late at night and it wasnt necessarily something that I wanted to do but I also didnt feel safe on public transportation as a Woman by myself

qa_pairs.question: What impact did the pandemic have on Sunshine Powers' business?
qa_pairs.answer: The pandemic was humbling; her business was the first small business in San Francisco to close, and it stayed closed for about a year. During this time, she revamped the shop and built an online store.
qa_pairs.source_text: with the pandemic that was humbling and we were the first small business in San Francisco to close and we stayed close for about a year during that time we uh redid the inside of the shop and outside the shop and I built an online store

qa_pairs.question: How does Sunshine Powers support her employees' housing needs?
qa_pairs.answer: Sunshine offers a housing credit to employees who have been with the company for over six months, and she has housed employees in apartments above the shop.
qa_pairs.source_text: were now offering a housing credit to anyone thats been here for over six months because I cant at this point provide affordable housing for them all I would like to um but that doesnt mean that I should treat other people differently if I cant like because I get a housing credit if they live above the shop and I might as well give the people that dont live above the shop that same housing credit because thats fair

qa_pairs.question: What is Sunshine Powers' view on housing allocation for small business employees?
qa_pairs.answer: Sunshine believes that housing projects should allocate part of their units to people who work for small businesses in the neighborhood to create better community.
qa_pairs.source_text: I really wish when theyre doing these housing projects like the 730 stand in that they allocated part of that to people that work for the small businesses inside the neighborhood because that just creates better community

qa_pairs.question: What is Sunshine Powers' perspective on public transportation as a woman?
qa_pairs.answer: Sunshine does not feel safe on public transportation as a woman, especially after the pandemic.
qa_pairs.source_text: I as a woman dont feel safe on public transportation and we just got rid of the pandemic so that I mean were still dealing with it

qa_pairs.question: How has housing employees impacted Sunshine Powers' business?
qa_pairs.answer: Since housing her employees, Sunshine's business has increased by 120%, and she feels it is a win-win for everyone.
qa_pairs.source_text: since I started housing the employees the business is up by 120 so you know I paid my employees more and I housed them and in turn my business more than doubled so for for me its a win-win for everybody

qa_pairs.question: What is Sunshine Powers' opinion on the city's real estate investments?
qa_pairs.answer: Sunshine believes the city should buy real estate to have equity investments, as it seems logical to her.
qa_pairs.source_text: I really dont understand why we as a city arent housing more people and this is totally off topic but I really dont understand as we as a city arent buying real estate because were spending and wasting so much money that we could actually buy real estate and have Equity Investments that just seem logical to me
